quote: Lookin' good. I say... five.
Five here.
And five more.
I believe the wiser course of   action here is to bend.
You mean fold.
That is correct. Fold -- to bend,   make compact or give in.
I raise fifty.
I do not believe Lieutenant Worf   understands all the nuances of   this betting procedure.
Don't be too quick to judge, Data.   His pile's a lot bigger than   yours.
Than all of ours.
The cards have been favoring the   Lieutenant, but that is the result   of random chance... hence it is   a temporary condition.
You hope.
Talk or play. Not both.
Fifty, right?
Fifty is the bet. What's the   matter -- are your feet getting   cold?
No, just my cards...
Thanks for staying in -- I need   the chips.
Got to earn them first.
Oh, I will. This pot has my name   on it.
Talk, talk, talk...
Here's some action. Fifty...       ... and another fifty.
Fold, fold, fold...
Your fifty, and fifty more.
Love to stay in -- but not with   these cards.
Looks like it's just you and me,   handsome.
I'll see you.
Beats my straight.
The Iceman wins again.
You took my last chip. You could   at least smile, Worf.
Smiling might break his   concentration.
If you don't enjoy winning -- what   do you enjoy? Losing?
We'd be happy to accommodate you.
Your deal.
The game is seven card stud; after   the queen, one-eyed jacks and low   card in the hole are wild.
Let me write this down.
Just deal. I'd like to get some   of my losings back before the next   century.
I open with fifty.
Bridge to Commander Riker. We   are receiving a class eleven   emergency signal from Starfleet   Command.
On my way.
Fifty? You were bluffing.
Klingons never bluff.
Mister Data?
Emergency signal reads as follows:   Enterprise to divert to   coordinates four-two-three by   one-one-two by five-one   immediately. Further orders   forthcoming.
That's it? What's the emergency?
The message does not elaborate.
You'd think they'd at least give   us a hint.
Course laid in, Captain.
Warp eight.       Whenever Starfleet gets enigmatic,   I know we're about to face a   challenge.
Engage.
Our destination is a point near   the Boradis system.
That area was colonized fairly   recently, as I recall.
The first Federation outpost was   established thirty-four years ago   on Boradis Three.
And since then, the Federation   has colonized several planets in   that sector.
Yet we are not headed for a   specific colony. The coordinates   given are outside the Boradis   system.
Any problems reported in that   area?
None.
Then what the devil's going on?
Captain, Starfleet Command is   hailing us.
It's about time. On screen.
Greetings, Captain Picard.
My compliments, Admiral Gromek.
Captain, you'll soon be joined   by a Federation special emissary   from Starbase one five three.   We're now transmitting the   specifics.
We are receiving.
The rendezvous will be a bit   tricky, so it's imperative you   reach the intercept point on   schedule.
Understood. And -- the mission?
The envoy will fill you in. You   are to cooperate fully.
Can you give me any details?
Negative.
Admiral, I find it difficult to   prepare for a mission I know   nothing about.
I sympathize, Jean-Luc, but   Starfleet Command considers this   a top-security matter.
After the envoy's briefed you,   I think you'll understand our   caution. Gromek out.
Data, what ship is carrying the   envoy?
The envoy is not aboard a   starship.
Indeed?
Apparently there were no starships   available at Starbase   one five three. The emissary is   aboard a class eight probe.
A class eight probe is just over   two meters long!
True, Number One. But if the   sensors and transmitters were   removed and life-support   installed, there would be just   enough space for one person.
And those probes are designed to   go warp nine.
By sending the probe to meet us   rather than diverting the   Enterprise to the starbase, they   have saved us six point one hours.
Obviously Starfleet feels that   time is of the essence.
Yes, but still... to seal someone   up inside a Class Eight Probe and   then just launch it off...       Hell of a way to transport a   Federation dignitary.
We'll need an intercept course   with pin-point accuracy. The   probe carrying the emissary has   no means of navigation...
... so if we don't catch it on the   first try, we'll have to chase   it.
Data -- if we project our course   past the rendezvous coordinates,   what lies ahead?
As far as I can determine, sir   -- very little. There are four   colonies in the Boradis system,   and nine other outposts scattered   throughout the sector.
Captain, we have a way to save   you some time.
Proceed.
I believe we can beam the probe   aboard while we're still   travelling at Warp Nine.
Quite a trick.
Right -- at warp speed it's   nearly impossible to get a solid   transporter lock. But if we   caught the probe with a tractor   beam...
We could use the tractor beam to   focus the transporter.
Exactly.
Risks?
None to the emissary. There's   a chance the probe could break   free... then we'd have to find   it and start over.
So it's a gamble.       Odds, gentlemen?
Twenty to one it'll work.
Make it so.
Coming to three-one mark one-one-three.
We should now be on a precisely   parallel course with the probe.
Increase to warp eight point nine.
Eight point nine -- aye.
Full sensors, aft.
Scanning...
I have it, sir. Bearing zero-five   mark two-three-one; velocity warp   nine.
I see it.
Adjust speed to intercept.
Probe coming up to starboard,   range eighty-two hundred.   Tractor beam ready.
Mister La Forge?
Transporter ready, Captain.
Range now seventy-five hundred.
Steady as she goes...
Probe is standing abeam.
Engage tractor.
Okay, O'Brien, they've hooked   it -- let's reel it in.
Will do.       Transporter beam locked, Captain.
Energize.
Probe aboard, Captain.
Acknowledged. Number One?
I'll welcome our visitor.
Resume original course and speed.
Aye, sir.
Well done, everyone.
Something wrong, Doctor?
I'm not sure. The readings are   quite... interesting.
I greet you. I am K'Ehleyr.
nuqneH. qaleghneS.
You speak Klingon.
A little. I am Commander Riker,   and this is our chief medical   officer, Katherine Pulaski.
I hope your voyage wasn't too   unpleasant.
Klingons are not supposed to mind   hardship.       Nonetheless -- I'm delighted to   be out of that damned coffin.
I don't blame you.       Not the most luxurious   accommodations Starfleet has to   offer...
Whoever said that getting there   is half the fun never rode in   a class eight probe.
How are you feeling? Your vital   signs are rather atypical for a   Klingon.
No doubt because I am only half   Klingon.
Oh?
Yes. My father was Klingon; my   mother was human.
Captain, I'd like to present   Special Federation Emissary   K'Ehleyr.
Welcome aboard. I'm Jean-Luc   Picard.       Counselor Troi, Lieutenant   Commander Data, and --
Worf! So this is where you've   been hiding. I told you we'd meet   again!
Aren't you going to greet me?
I have nothing to say to you.
Haven't changed a bit, eh? Well,   I missed you, too.
Two days ago, Starbase three three six   received an automated   transmission from a Klingon ship,   the T'Ong.       That ship was sent out over   seventy-five years ago.
When the Federation and the   Klingon Empire were still at   war...
The message was directed to the   Klingon High Command. It said   only that the T'Ong was returning   home and was about to reach the   "awakening point."
Which suggests that the crew was   in cryogenic sleep for most of   the long voyage.
Exactly.
And when the crew is revived...
... we'll have a ship full of   Klingons who think the war is   still going on.
So our task is to find the ship,   and tell the Klingons we are no   longer at war.
Why us? A Klingon ship would have   been a better choice.
A Klingon ship -- the P'rang --   is on its way, but it's two days   behind us. That may be too late.
Why too late?
Because the T'Ong's crew is about   to awaken within striking range   of a dozen Federation outposts.
There are thirteen colonies   with minimal defenses in that   sector...
Nice ripe targets for a Klingon   warship.
And you believe you can convince   these Klingons that humans are   now their allies?
No. Not a chance.

If you ask me, talking will be   a waste of time. Klingons of that   era were raised to despise humans.       We'll try diplomacy. But I   promise you -- it won't work.   And then you'll have to destroy   them.
No.
No? Captain, these Klingons are   killers. You'll have no choice.
Find me another choice. I want   some options -- and I want them   before we encounter the Klingon   ship.       Lieutenant, I'm assigning you to   help the emissary. Dismissed.
I'll escort you to the guest   quarters.
Lieutenant?
Sir... I suggest Commander Riker   or Data would better serve Special   Emissary K'Ehleyr.
Are there personal reasons you   don't want the assignment?
Yes.
Any professional reasons?
No.
I withdraw my request, Captain.
Good.
I didn't know it was possible   for a human and a Klingon to   produce a child.
Actually, the DNA is compatible   -- with a fair amount of help.       Rather like my parents.
I know exactly what you mean.   My father was human... and my   mother was Betazoid.
Really! It was the other way   around for me -- my mother was   human.       You must've grown up like I did   -- trapped between cultures.
I never felt trapped -- I felt   fortunate. I experienced the   richness and diversity of two   worlds.
(shakes her head in     wonder)   Perhaps you got the best of   each...
Myself, I think I got the worst   of each.
I doubt that.
Oh, yes. Having my mother's sense   of humor is bad enough -- it's   gotten me into plenty of trouble.
And your Klingon side?
That, I keep under tight control.   It's like a terrible temper --   it's not something I want people   to see.
Why hide it? We all have   tempers...
Not like mine. Sometimes I feel   there's a monster inside me,   fighting to get out.
And that frightens you.
Of course it does. My Klingon   side can be terrifying... even   to me.
Yet it gives you strength. It's   part of you.
That doesn't mean I have to like   it.
You are late.
Sorry. Had to make myself   beautiful.
I fail to understand why.
Worf, we're alone now. You don't   have to act like a Klingon   glacier. I don't bite...       ... well, that's wrong; I do bite.
Shall we proceed with our assigned   duties?
I haven't even had a proper   welcome.
I would prefer to keep this   professional.
"I fail to understand why."
And I feel no need to explain.
Oh, go ahead. Tell me. It's   because you find me irresistible,   isn't it? You always have.
Did you come on board the   Enterprise to work, or to discuss   your pointless fantasies?
You just won't open up, will you?   Come on -- what happened to the   Worf I met on Samrin's Planet?
He became a Starfleet lieutenant.
Oh, is that it? Starfleet Academy   turned you into a robot? You   won't make me believe that.
I have no wish to make you believe   anything.
Perhaps you have changed. You   weren't this aloof six years   ago... or don't you remember?
There is nothing wrong with my   memory.
Well, there's something wrong with   the rest of you. You're not even   looking at me.
I am familiar with your   appearance.
And it gives you no pleasure to   see me again?
It isn't as if we tried it and   it didn't work, you know. You   never gave it a chance.
I never?
I mean, as I see it, we have   some... unfinished business, you   and I.
Not as far as I'm concerned.
According to the library computer,   the captain of the T'Ong is   K'Temoc. But there is nothing   regarding the ship's mission.
So?
You're not interested in why the   ship was sent out?
Probably some secret military   objective.
Perhaps, but we have no evidence   of that --
Why else would there be no record   of the mission?
The records may simply have been   lost.
In any case, what does it matter?   Our concern is the present -- the   possible threat.
And to contend with that threat,   we need information.
We have all the information we   need.
That is foolish. Knowing their   mission might help us understand   them --
There's nothing to understand!   They're Klingons! They'll attack!   In their minds, we're the enemy   -- and there's no way we're going   to talk them out of that!
I do not appreciate being   interrupted.
And I don't appreciate wasting   my time.
We were instructed to come up with   options --
There aren't any! The   assignment's hopeless!
There are always options.
Oh, are there? Tell me: whatever   happened to that wonderful   Klingon fatalism of yours?
My experience aboard this ship   has taught me that most problems   have more than one solution.
Starfleet hasn't improved you   one bit. You're as stubborn as   ever!
Are you going to carry out your   duties or aren't you?
All right! I will!
Upon due consideration of the   problem and careful examination   of all possible "options" -- my   original recommendation stands.
Meeting adjourned.
Come.
You're upset.
Really! Your finely-honed   Betazoid sense tells you that?
Well -- that, and the table.
I warned you about my Klingon   half.
May I make a suggestion?
I thank you, Counselor. But I   don't want any counseling.
Actually, I was going to suggest   something else.
Oh?
I find the Holodeck exercise   programs rigorous enough to put   my mind off most frustrations.

That, too...
Enter program.
Show me the exercise menu.
Calisthenics program of Lieutenant   Worf.
Program complete. You may enter   when ready.
Status.
Based on the last assumed position   of the Klingon vessel, its   apparent trajectory, and our   estimates of their cruising speed,   we should be in scanner range in   fifteen hours, eight minutes.
Lieutenant?
Special Emissary K'Ehleyr has...   declared a short recess, sir.   I wish to run a full diagnostic   test on all tactical back-up   equipment.
We just ran a full test of those   systems.
I feel it necessary to check them   again.
Lieutenant, I commend your   diligence. However, I'm concerned   that you're working yourself too   hard.
Sir, considering the unknown   elements we are about to face --
Lieutenant -- I order you to   relax.
I am relaxed.       Yes, sir.
I've never seen the Lieutenant   so... unsettled.
The Iceman's finally melting.
It's not much of a program.
Computer. Level Two.
Some calisthenics programs are   better than others.
You can still make jokes?
Of course I can. I still have   enough energy for that...       You're not laughing.
You are most observant.
You don't like people with a sense   of humor?
I did not say that.
Worf, you're the perfect Klingon   -- the ultimate minimalist. Talk   to me!
I've noted that some people use   humor as a shield... they talk   much yet say little.
Whereas others take a simpler   approach -- say nothing.
When one does not have the   words...
Or is loath to speak them...
Fortunately, there are other ways   to communicate.       Why didn't we do this six years   ago?
We were not ready.
I was...
We were both too young -- too   unaware. We lacked commitment.
Perhaps we lacked courage as well.
No longer.
tlhIngan jIH.
Wait. You can't mean -- You're   not --
We have mated.
Yes, I know -- I was there.   But...
And now we must solemnize our   union with the oath --
Like hell we must!
-- and pledge that we are one   forever.
I'm not going to become your   wife...
You already are.
Don't give me that Klingon   nonsense.
You would dishonor our sacred   traditions?
They're not sacred -- they're   absurd! Marrying you is out of   the question for a million   reasons...
None of which stopped you earlier.
Worf, it was what it was!   Glorious and wonderful and all   that, but it doesn't mean   anything.

I am human!

And that means we should bond for   life?

Yours -- not mine!
tlhIngan jIH!

Full impulse. Engage.

I am here to assist you.
Unwilling to be alone with me?

An android chaperone?

Never mind. Come on in.       I guess I can't blame you.
Tell me one thing.
You would have gone through with   the oath, wouldn't you?   Regardless of the consequences   to our careers -- to our lives?
Honor demanded no less.
I'm sick to death of Klingon   "honor." What do you want? Is   honor all you care about? Don't   you feel anything else?
No comment, huh?
Poor android. Which behavior do   you find more perplexing -- human   or Klingon?
At the moment, I would be hard   pressed to choose.
So would I.
Okay. When we locate the T'Ong,   there are two possibilities.   First --
-- we find the ship before it   reaches the "awakening point."   In that case, we could simply keep   the crew asleep.
Is that feasible?
We can beam an away team onto the   T'Ong and override the cryogenic   controls.
Then we await the arrival of the   Klingon ship P'rang...
... so that when the T'Ong's crew   awakens, they're surrounded by   their fellow Klingons.
That would be ideal.
But there's the second   possibility... that the crew of   the T'Ong has already revived.
They discover they're in   Federation territory -- and they   attack the nearest outpost.
Are we sure they'll attack?
We don't even know what the   T'Ong's mission was.
It may have been a scientific   voyage.
Klingons of that period -- doing   research for its own sake?
The point is, they may not be   warlike.
The point is that this is beside   the point. These are Klingons...   at war with us. Whatever their   mission was -- once they see a   Federation target, they'll attack.
Could the T'Ong be disabled rather   than destroyed?
We could probably knock out their   warp engines without damaging the   rest of their ship...
That would gain you nothing.   Disable the ship, and K'Temoc will   destroy it himself.
Klingons do not surrender.
Face it -- if we don't reach the   T'Ong before its crew wakes up,   you have no alternatives.
I will not accept that. There   must be a way to make the Klingons   listen. If we can only convince   them --
Captain, we have detected a ship,   bearing three-one-six mark   forty-two, extreme sensor range.
Plot an intercept course. And   go to Yellow Alert.
Shields are up.
Better lock on phasers. This may   be the only chance you get.
Intercept course laid in.
Hold this position. Let's see   if they've spotted us.       Magnification one hundred.
Mister Data?

However, I could be in error.
Shields holding.
They've cloaked themselves.
Well, Captain -- you had your   chance.
Transfer Engineering to bridge.
Can you find them?

I think so. Those old shields   weren't a hundred percent   efficient at blocking gamma-ray   output. If I can tune the sensors   to a particular band of...       There! Got 'em! Transferring   coordinates to helm...
Intercept. Warp two.
Warp two, sir.
Captain -- let them die like   Klingons... in battle. They   deserve that much.
Captain... I have another option.
The T'Ong has changed course to   three-two mark eight-one. They   are increasing to warp three.
Standard evasive maneuver.
Helm -- stay with them.
Yes, sir.
The T'Ong is now on a heading of   four-one mark one-one-three...   accelerating to warp five.
They're making a break for it.
Overtake. Warp eight.
Aye.
Put us right in their path and   come to a full stop.       Full power to shields.
Full power, sir.

They are slowing to impulse --
Phaser hit on forward shields.   No damage.

Compensate.
Photon torpedo hit. Shield number   two weakened... firming up now...   No damage.
I think we've piqued their   curiosity by now...

Ready, Lieutenant?       Open a hailing frequency.
Hailing frequency open, sir.
What --
